messages.content: Do you feel the performance review process is fair?
Not always. It feels like a checkbox exercise, and ratings don’t always reflect actual contributions.
Would you report a concern if you saw someone being mistreated?
Yes, if I’m confident it will be taken seriously and the person affected will be protected.
Was the onboarding content relevant?
Only partially. Some sessions felt like generic compliance slides rather than real job prep.
How are you coping with work-related stress?
I’ve developed my own coping mechanisms, like setting strict boundaries after hours and taking short walks during the day. But sometimes, the stress catches up, especially when deadlines overlap.
How do you feel about working at this company overall?

Overall, I feel good working here. The culture is relatively positive, and there’s a sense of freedom in how I manage my time. I enjoy working with my team, people are respectful and collaborative. That said, there are times when communication feels rushed or incomplete, especially when changes are made. Still, I appreciate the growth I’ve had here so far.
What made you decide to leave the organization?
It was a mix of limited growth opportunities and feeling stagnant. I voiced my interest in trying new roles but didn’t get much support. Eventually, I realized I needed a change.
Do you feel comfortable discussing mental health with peers or supervisors?
With peers and friends - yes. With my supervisor, not really. There’s a silent expectation to just “deal with it” and not let personal issues interfere with work.
Do you feel emotionally safe in your current team environment?
For the most part, yes. We share laughs, celebrate wins, and I can be myself without judgment. But I do wish there was more openness about failures or asking for help.
Would you recommend this company to others?
Yes, but with caveats. It’s a good place to start your career or learn fast, but it may not be ideal for long-term growth unless you're in a high-visibility team.
How do policies impact your day-to-day work?
Policies shape everything — from how I apply for leave to what benefits I can use. When they’re unclear or inconsistently applied, it slows me down.
Do you feel your opinions are valued at work?
In team discussions, yes, I feel heard. But when it comes to policy-level decisions, it sometimes feels like feedback is collected but not acted upon.
Have you experienced or witnessed any inappropriate behavior at work?

I did witness a situation where a team member made repeated sarcastic comments toward a female colleague during meetings. She brushed it off publicly, but I could tell it made her uncomfortable. I’m not sure if it was escalated formally, but I do think the manager should’ve intervened.
Have you ever felt overlooked or dismissed by your manager?
Once or twice, yes, especially during performance reviews where I felt my input wasn’t fully considered.
Have you used any mental health resources the company provides?
Not yet. I didn’t know exactly how to access them or what they cover. Maybe an internal awareness campaign would help.
Do you feel confident giving feedback on company policies?
I’ve given feedback through surveys, but I’m not sure if it went anywhere. It’d be great to hear back about what changed based on employee input.
Do you feel your career goals are understood by your manager?
We’ve discussed it once, but I don’t think there's a concrete plan yet. I'd appreciate regular check-ins.
Do you feel the company supports mental health openly?
I think the intent is there, we have EAPs and wellness days, but the culture still glorifies overworking. If leadership took a stand on balance, it’d normalize using those benefits.
How frequently do you receive feedback from your manager?
Maybe once a month during check-ins, but I wish it was more regular and impromptu, even informal and quick conversation can help course correct before a project ends.
Was your manager well-prepared for the review?
Seemed like they rushed through it. I doubt they had gone through my work in detail.
How do you feel about the way your departure is being handled?
It’s been respectful and professional. I’ve had my offboarding checklist, HR has been helpful, and my manager scheduled a proper handover.
What’s one policy you think needs to be added or revised?
A formal policy on hybrid/remote work expectations. Right now it’s arbitrary, and people are unsure when they’re expected in office.
What aspects of your work do you find frustrating?
Sometimes, decision-making is too top-down. Also, it feels like we're always in a rush, there’s no breathing room to reflect or course correct. It leads to errors and burnout.
How confident are you in your manager’s leadership style?
Fairly confident, though I think it leans too much toward operations. I’d love to see more visionary thinking and inspirational communication.
Do you feel safe raising concerns about harassment or misconduct?
I would like to say yes, but I’m hesitant. While the policies exist on paper, I’m not entirely sure how they’re enforced. And people still worry about being labeled a troublemaker if they speak up.
Are you aware of the company’s POSH policy?
I’ve read it, yes. It was part of the onboarding documents. But don't remember exactly now. A refresher session every 6 months would be helpful.
Have you ever considered taking a mental health day?
Yes, and I’ve taken one or two. Thankfully, my manager was understanding. But I didn’t feel comfortable announcing it as a mental health day — I just said I wasn’t feeling well.
Do you think leaders are trained to handle sensitive issues well?
Some are, but not all. I’ve seen managers ignore mental health comments or uncomfortable interactions because they don’t know how to handle them.
Were you satisfied with the outcome?
No. I didn’t get the hike I expected, and there was no clarity on what to do differently.
Do you feel your manager fosters your professional growth?
That’s one area where we could do better. I’ve had to initiate all conversations around growth and learning. I’d appreciate it if they were more proactive in identifying opportunities for me.
What are your manager’s strengths?
They’re calm under pressure and very detail-oriented. They know how to break down complex issues, which makes it easier for the team to execute.
How can the review process be improved?
Add peer feedback, make it more frequent, and set clearer goals from both sides.
Have you ever felt a policy was unfair or biased?
Yes, the current promotion policy seems to favor people in client-facing roles over backend teams, regardless of contribution.
Where do you see your career in the company in the next 2 years?
I’d like to move into a strategy or planning role, and I hope to lead a small team by then. But it depends on internal opportunities opening up.
Has the grievance redressal mechanism worked for you or anyone you know?
A former teammate filed a complaint and the resolution took a very long time. While the intent seemed there, the pace and communication from HR were not reassuring.
What suggestions do you have for improving workplace wellness?
Train managers to spot burnout. Also, make wellness discussions part of monthly check-ins, not just something we do during crises.
How approachable is your manager?
My manager is approachable and generally responsive, but they’re often stretched too thin. I sometimes hesitate to bring up small issues because I know they’re juggling a lot.
Do you feel your work is aligned with the company’s vision?
To some extent, yes. I understand the larger goals, but I don’t always see how my individual tasks tie back into that. A more regular business update or team strategy sync might help with that.
Were your expectations from the role and company met?
Partially. The role was as described, but the culture was more hierarchical than I had expected.
How was your recent performance review experience?
It was brief and vague. I was hoping for more specific feedback and a development plan.
What are the few things you enjoy about working here?

First, I genuinely like the people, they’re helpful and sharp. Second, the projects are interesting and often push me to learn new things. And third, the flexibility around work hours has been a huge plus, especially when juggling personal responsibilities.
Do you think current policies reflect the needs of employees?
Not entirely. For example, the policy on reimbursements is outdated. It assumes paper receipts and physical forms when everything else is digital now.
What could the company do to improve employee safety and grievance handling?
Encourage anonymous reporting. Also, have regular workshops or townhalls where leaders reaffirm their zero-tolerance stance. It builds trust over time.
Did you feel welcomed when you joined?
Yes, my team was warm. But structurally, I wish there had been a buddy system.
How would you rate the support you received from your team/manager?
It was good initially, but declined over time as team priorities shifted. I often had to fend for myself toward the end.
How has your mental health evolved since joining this company?
Initially, I was enthusiastic and driven. But over time, the constant hustle and lack of downtime made me more anxious. I’ve had to consciously slow down and reprioritize.
Are the company policies easy to understand and follow?
Some are clear, like leave and travel. Others, like hybrid work expectations, are vague. It feels like interpretation depends on the team you’re in.
How well are policy updates communicated?
They’re usually sent over email, but often without any real explanation of the “why” behind the change. People read them and move on without fully understanding.
How satisfied are you with your current role and responsibilities?

I'm somewhat satisfied. I like the core responsibilities, but I think my skill set is being underutilized. I’d love to work on projects that align more closely with data and strategy which is my core skillset.
